revisions.rev:
{{about|the United States-based airline|the Australia-based airline|Horizon Airlines (Australia)}} {{Infobox Airline | airline = Horizon Air | image = Horizon Air Logo.svg | image_size = | IATA = QX | ICAO = QXE | callsign = HORIZON AIR | founded = 1981 | commenced = September 1, 1981 | ceased = | aoc = | bases = | hubs =
* [[Portland International Airport]] * [[Seattle-Tacoma International Airport]] | secondary_hubs =
* [[Los Angeles International Airport]] | focus_cities = | frequent_flyer = Mileage Plan | lounge = Board Room | subsidiaries = | fleet_size = 57 | destinations = 47 | parent = [[Alaska Air Group]] | company_slogan = Wings of the Great Northwest | headquarters = [[SeaTac, Washington]]"[http://web.archive.org/web/19981201225853/www.alaskaair.com/help/contacts/html/email.stm Contact Phone Numbers]." [[Alaska Air Group]]. December 1, 1998. Retrieved on July 23, 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.alaskasworld.com/newsroom/QXNews/QX-Fact-Sheet_Overview.asp|title=Overview|month=January | year=2008|work=Horizon Air Company Facts|publisher=Alaska Air Group|accessdate=2008-10-11}} | key_people = Glenn Johnson (President) | website = http://www.horizonair.com/ }} [[File:Horizon Air 44539.JPG|thumb|Horizon Air headquarters]] '''Horizon Air Industries, Inc.''' ([[d/b/a]] '''Horizon Air'''){{cite web|url=http://www.iata.org/ps/certification/iosa/operator?c=QXE|title=IOSA Operational Safety Audit|publisher=[[International Air Transport Association]]|accessdate=2008-10-22 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080511174904/http://www.iata.org/ps/certification/iosa/operator?c=QXE |archivedate = 2008-05-11}} is a [[regional airline|regional]] [[low-cost carrier|low-cost airline]] based in [[SeaTac, Washington|SeaTac]], [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]], United States."[http://www.alaskasworld.com/Newsroom/ASnews/media.asp Media Contacts: Alaska Airlines]," ''Alaska Airlines''"[http://www1.cityofseatac.com/everywherespossible/Business/WhySeaTac/TopIndustries/tabid/65/Default.aspx TOP INDUSTRIES]." ''City of SeaTac''. Retrieved July 20, 2008."[http://www.ci.seatac.wa.us/localmaps/zoning.pdf City of SeaTac Zoning]." ''City of SeaTac''. Retrieved August 20, 2008. It is the eighth largest regional airline in the USA, serving 52 cities in the United States, Canada and Mexico. Horizon Air and its sister carrier [[Alaska Airlines]] are subsidiaries of [[Alaska Air Group]]. It is also a substantial [[codeshare]] partner of [[American Airlines]] and [[Delta Air Lines]]. == History == ===1980s=== [[File:Horizon f27.jpg|thumb|left|A Horizon Air [[Fairchild Hiller FH-227|Fairchild F27]] at [[Spokane International Airport]]. (1993)]] Horizon Air was formed in May 1981 by Milt Kuolt, and started operations on September 1, 1981 with three [[Fairchild F-27]] aircraft.Endicott 2001, p. 32 The airline was formed as a merger of Horizon Airlines and [[Air Oregon]] in 1982. Its headquarters were in an area that is now within [[SeaTac, Washington]]."World Airline Directory." ''[[Flight International]]''. March 31, 1984. [http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1984/1984%20-%200560.html?search=%22Horizon%20Air%22 844]. Horizon Air's first route was from [[Yakima, Washington|Yakima]] to [[Seattle]], and one week later, [[Pasco, Washington|Pasco]] to Seattle.Endicott 2001, p. 52 The general offices of Horizon Air were operated out of an old house behind Sea-Tac airport. Horizon acquired [[Air Oregon]] on June 17, 1982, after both airlines were losing hundreds of thousands of dollars monthly, in order to consolidate and reduce their operating deficit.Endicott 2001, pg. 119-125 Horizon agreed to purchase [[Transwestern Airlines]] of Utah in September 1983, once again to try to reduce operating deficit of the airline.{{cite news|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?idf=Ma8SAAAAIBAJ&sjid=cvkDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2623,1012698&dq=transwestern+airlines|title=Horizon buys Utah airline|last=[[Associated Press]]|date=1983-09-13|work=[[Spokane Chronicle]]|publisher=[[Google News Archives]]|accessdate=2009-09-15}} A single [[Fokker F28]] was the first jet owned by Horizon Air, purchased from a carrier in Africa, in July 1984, however their first jet was a [[wet lease]]d [[Douglas DC-9]].Endicott 2001, p. 141 An [[initial public offering]] occurred in 1984 to secure operating capital, which after only one profitable year since founding, was needed to keep the airline afloat.{{cite news|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=9WoVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=k-EDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5504,7628871&dq=horizon-air+stock|title=Horizon Air says it plans to issue stock|last=AP|date=1995-05-30|work=[[Eugene Register-Guard]]|publisher=Google News Archives|accessdate=2009-09-15}} On September 8, 1985 Horizon signed an agreement with [[de Havilland Canada]] to begin purchasing the airline's first brand new aircraft, the [[Bombardier Dash 8|de Haviland Dash 8]].{{cite news|title=Annual Report, 1985|publisher=Horizon Air|page=1|accessdate=2009-09-15}}{{cite news|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=JLcSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=pPkDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2580,569222&dq=horizon-air|title=Horizon Air orders 10 planes|date=1985-09-04|work=Spokane Chronicle|publisher=Google News Archives|accessdate=2009-09-15}} In the summer of 1985, Horizon entered into its first [[codeshare agreement]] with [[United Airlines]],Endicott 2001, p. 220 which attracted the attention of [[Alaska Airlines]] who finally purchased Horizon in 1986.Endicott 2001, p. 230 Late in 1985 Horizon entered into an agreement to purchase their chief competitor in Washington, [[Cascade Airways]],{{cite news|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=U7YSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=r_kDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6012,206560&dq=horizon-air|title=Horizon buying Cascade|last=Associated Press|date=1985-08-01|work=Spokane Chronicle|publisher=Google News Archives|accessdate=2009-09-15}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} but by early 1986 were released from the agreement.{{cite news|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=QP8RAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Pe8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=3593,4835890&dq=horizon-air|title=Horizon released from agreement to buy Cascade|last=Bartel|first=Frank|work=[[Spokane Spokesman-Review]]|publisher=Google News Archives|accessdate=2009-09-15}} In 1988 Horizon signed a codeshare agreement with [[Northwest Airlines]]. In 1989, Horizon became an international carrier when it began service to [[Vancouver, BC]] and [[Victoria, BC]] in May of that year using both Dash-8-100s and [[Fairchild Swearingen Metroliner]]. ===1990s=== [[File:Horizon Air Dash 8 landing at Portland airport.jpg|thumb|right|A Horizon Air [[Bombardier Dash 8|Bombardier Q200]] lands at [[Portland International Airport]]. (2008)]] {{Unreferenced section|date=April 2011}} {{expand section|date=September 2009}} Horizon was the launch customer for the [[Dornier 328]] turboprop, intending to replace the Fairchild Metroliners with this new aircraft which promised jetliner speed and comfort.{{citation needed|date+=April 2011|date=April 2011}} Prototype#2 was painted in Horizon colors.{{citation needed|date=April 2011}} Twelve were delivered between November 1993 and November 1995, but they were quickly phased out in 1997 in favor of fleet standardization around the Dash-8.{{citation needed|date=April 2011}} ===2000s=== {{expand section|more information of events in the early 2000s.|date=September 2009}} In the spring of 2007, Horizon launched service from Los Angeles and Seattle to Santa Rosa, California to take advantage of the burgeoning wine and tourism industry. This was a significant coup {{citation needed|date=December 2010}} for the Sonoma County region which had not had regularly scheduled air service in almost six years. The new routes proved so popular that in the fall of 2007, Horizon commenced non stop service from Portland, OR to Santa Rosa, and expanded the schedule for non stop flights between Los Angeles and Santa Rosa. It is wholly owned by the Alaska Air Group and has 4,040 employees (at March 2007).{{cite news | title= Directory: World Airlines | work= [[Flight International]] | page= 91 | date= 2007-04-03}} Horizon Air has been featured in several films, including the 1983 motion picture ''[[WarGames]]'' and 1995 motion picture ''[[Georgia (1995 film)]]''. ===2010s=== [[File:Horizon Q400 LAX N423QX.jpg|thumb|left|A [[Bombardier Q400]] in Alaska/Horizon livery, reflecting the retirement of the Horizon Air brand]] On August 23, 2010, it was announced that Horizon's business model was to change to having all decisions about route choices and marketing services being made by Alaska Airlines by the beginning of 2011. The business model Alaska Air Group Inc. is adapting is called the "Capacity Purchase Agreement." The change would mean that all ticket revenue would go to Alaska Airlines, and Horizon's operating costs would be covered by Alaska Airlines. Before the change, limited amounts of Horizon routes had been operated as such, but more had been run entirely by Horizon.{{cite web|title=Horizon Air Changes Business Model|url=http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story_generic.jsp?channel=aviationdaily&id=news/avd/2010/08/23/08.xml&headline=Horizon%20Air%20Changes%20Business%20Model|publisher=Aviation Week|accessdate=26 August 2010|date=23 August 2010}} On January 25, 2011, Alaska Airlines announced{{citation needed|date=October 2011}} that it will be retiring the Horizon Air brand. All Horizon planes will be repainted in the trademarked eskimo Alaska livery, but the service and extras Horizon is known for{{citation needed|date=October 2011}} will stay the same. ==Management== Glenn Johnson was appointed President of Horizon Air in June 2010, replacing the retiring CEO and President Jeff Pinneo. Johnson joined Alaska Airlines in 1982 as a staff auditor and was promoted to Director of Revenue Accounting. In 1991, he joined Horizon as Vice President of Finance and Treasurer, and was then promoted to Senior Vice President of Customer Services. In 2003, Johnson returned to Alaska to serve as Vice President of Finance and Treasurer for Alaska Air Group and Alaska Airlines, and he was subsequently promoted to Executive Vice President and CFO. == Destinations == [[File:Horizon Air Q400 (Mammoth Yosemite Airport, 2010).JPG|thumb|right|A Horizon Air [[Bombardier Dash 8|Bombardier Q400]] at [[Mammoth Yosemite Airport]] in [[Mammoth Lakes, California]]. (2010)]] {{main|Horizon Air destinations}} Horizon's 47 destinations are located in the U.S. states of Arizona, California, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, Oregon, and Washington. Horizon also has service to Alberta and British Columbia, Canada as well as Baja California Sur, Mexico. [[Codeshare|Codesharing]] with [[Alaska Airlines]], [[American Airlines]],{{cite web|url=http://www.aa.com/aa/i18nForward.do?p=/aboutUs/codesharePartners/main.jsp|title=Codeshare Partners|publisher=[[American Airlines]]|accessdate=2008-11-01}} and [[Delta Air Lines]] allows Horizon Air customers to fly to cities not served by Horizon Air throughout the U.S. as well as the rest of the world.{{cite news|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/archives/1988/8802030759.asp|title=Horizon / Northwest Airlines will soon begin coordination of services|date=1988-12-16|publisher=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]|pages=B6|accessdate=2008-10-11}} == Fleet == [[File:N427QX-2008-09-13-YVR.jpg|thumb|right|A Horizon Air [[Bombardier Dash 8|Bombardier Q400]] landing at [[Vancouver International Airport]]. (2008)]] Horizon Air operates 49 [[narrow-body aircraft]] as of June 2011, with a single [[economy class]] service:{{cite web|url=http://www.alaskaair.com/content/about-us/newsroom/qx-fleet.aspx|title=Fleet|month=September | year=2009|work=Horizon Air Company Facts|publisher=Alaska Air Group|accessdate=2009-09-20}} {| class="wikitable" style="margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto;" |+ '''Horizon Air Fleet''' |- !Aircraft !Total !Orders !Passengers
(Economy) |- |[[Bombardier Dash 8|Bombardier Q400]] |
48
|
1
|
76
|} The average Horizon Air fleet age is 6 years old as of June 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.airfleets.net/ageflotte/?file=calcop&opp=Horizon%20Air|title=Airline fleet age - Horizon Air|publisher=Airfleets.net|accessdate=2011-06-18}} The Q400 is a 74 or 76 seat, high-wing [[turboprop]]. All Horizon Air aircraft are operated in a single class configuration. Each row has two seats on either side of the aisle. As such, there are no middle seats on Horizon, only window or aisle. Horizon Air features all leather seating.{{cite web|url=http://www.alaskaair.com/content/travel-info/fleet/q400.aspx|title=Bombardier Q400 Aircraft Information|accessdate=2011-06-18}} In May 2011, [[SkyWest Airlines]] would begin operating six of Alaska Airlines' West Coast routes using five Bombardier CRJ-700s purchased from Horizon Air. SkyWest owns, operates and maintains the aircraft, while Alaska Airlines schedules, prices and markets the flights.http://travel.usatoday.com/flights/story/2011/02/Alaska-Airlines-signs-flying-deal-with-SkyWest/44166418/1 Alaska Airlines signs flying deal with SkyWest ===Fleet history=== [[File:QXcr7DEN2 edit.JPG|thumb|A Horizon Air [[Bombardier CRJ700|CRJ-700]] at [[Denver International Airport]] in 2007. The CRJ-700s were retired in mid-2011.]] Aircraft that have been in service with Horizon Air are (in alphabetical order): * [[Bombardier Dash 8|Bombardier Dash 8-100]]{{cite web|url=http://www.ch-aviation.ch|title=CH-Aviation Fleet Lists|accessdate=2009-09-19}} * [[Bombardier Dash 8|Bombardier Q200]] * [[Bombardier CRJ700]] * [[Dornier 328]]{{Cite book | author=Endres, GÃ¼nter G. | title=The illustrated directory of modern commercial aircraft | year=2001 | publisher=MBI Pub. Co. | location=Osceola, WI | isbn=978-0-7603-1125-7 | page=299}} * [[Douglas DC-9]]{{cite news|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=9bMSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hfkDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4457,219907&dq=horizon-air|title=Pasco to be served by jets|last=Associated Press|date=1984-07-02|work=Spokane Chronicle|publisher=Google News Archives|accessdate=2009-09-15}} * [[Fairchild F-27]]{{cite news|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/archives/1988/8801110601.asp|title=Horizon Air Began Flying in '81|last=Gorlick|first=Arthur C.|date=1988-04-16|work=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]|accessdate=2008-10-11}} * [[Fairchild Swearingen Metroliner|Fairchild Metroliner II]] (former [[Air Oregon]]) * [[Fairchild Swearingen Metroliner|Fairchild Metroliner III]] (former Air Oregon)Endicott 2001, p. 94{{cite news|url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19900612&slug=1076800|title=Faa: Window Trouble On Fairchild Planes Ongoing|last=Guillen|first=Tomas|date=1990-06-12|work=[[The Seattle Times]]|accessdate=2008-10-11}} * [[Fokker F28]]{{cite news|url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19990927&slug=2985513|title=An Airline Divided -- Horizon Air Is No Longer Tiny, And It's No Longer One Big, Happy Family, Either|last=Song|first=Kyung M.|date=1999-09-27|work=The Seattle Times|accessdate=2008-10-12}} On May 31, 2011, Horizon Air phased out the last of its CRJ-700 planes and now operates only the Q400.{{cite news|url=http://www.atwonline.com/news/story.html?storyID=13207|title=ATW Daily News|date=2008-07-01|publisher=[[Air Transport World]]|accessdate=2008-10-13}} In January 2007, the Q200s were removed from Horizon Air service and were [[dry lease]]d to [[CommutAir]].{{cite press release| title = CommutAir/Continental Connection concludes transaction for larger aircraft| publisher = [[CommutAir]]| date =2006-09-12| url = http://www.commutair.com/PressReleases/PressRelease20060912-Q200.pdf |format=PDF|title=Dash 8 acquisition| accessdate = 2007-02-10 }} === Livery === At the start of the carrier, Horizon had a painted sunset with a small beach with capitalized words saying "Horizon". Until recently, the current Horizon Air livery was very similar to its parent, Alaska Airlines, except for a dark red (rather than blue) [[Aircraft livery#Cheatline|cheatline]], and the tail includes a stylized sun and sunset logo, rather than an [[Eskimo]]. Eleven Q400s are currently painted in special liveries. Some Dash 8-200's (no longer in service with Horizon Air) had names of Horizon destinations printed near the front left door. On January 25, 2011 Horizon Air announced it was retiring its public brand and adopted the trademark Eskimo of its sister company, Alaska Airlines, on its fleet. As part of the brand change, Horizon's Bombardier Q400 fleet will be repainted with a new paint scheme prominently featuring "Alaska" across the fuselage and the Eskimo on the tail. The plane will continue to include the Horizon logo on the sides of the aircraft, which will now appear in Alaska's dark blue color. === Special liveries === [[File:Horizon Air Dash 8 Q-400.jpg|thumb|right|The Horizon Air [[Bombardier Dash 8|Bombardier Q400]] in Horizon Air ''"25th Anniversary"'' theme.]] Eleven Q400s are painted in special liveries: * N425QX is a 25th anniversary theme, featuring bright colors and confetti painted along the entire plane. Casually referred to as either "The Party Plane" or "Skittles."{{citation needed|date=July 2011}} * Two aircraft are painted in the "Comfortably Greener" scheme to highlight the fuel-saving attributes of the Q400 over regional jets. One is N439QX, and N438QX was later painted in the same scheme;{{cite news|url=http://www.alaskasworld.com/Newsroom/QXNews/QXstories/QX_20091117_081506.asp|title=Horizon Air Unveils 'Comfortably Greener' Q400 Livery|date=2009-11-17|publisher=Horizon Air|accessdate=2010-01-01}} together, these two planes are casually referred to as "Shrek" and "Fiona."{{citation needed|date=July 2011}} Many of the airline's special liveries feature the colors and logos of universities located in the Pacific Northwest.[http://seattle.bizjournals.com/seattle/stories/2010/10/04/daily5.html Horizon Air to add more college logos to planes] ''Puget Sound Business Journal'' These include: * N400QX for the [[University of Idaho]] Vandals{{cite news|url=http://www.fox12idaho.com/Global/story.asp?S=13267693|title=Idaho Vandals Get Horizon Plane|date=2010-10-05|publisher=aUIalumni|accessdate=2010-10-07}} * N401QX for the [[Washington State University]] Cougars * N402QX for the [[University of Montana]] Grizzlies * N403QX for the [[Montana State University â Bozeman|Montana State University]] Bobcats * N407QX for the [[University of Oregon]] Ducks * N435QX for the [[University of Washington]] Huskies, to replace the now-retired UW-themed CRJ, which formerly featured the same colors.{{cite press release |title=Horizon Air Flying Q400 with University of Washington Colors |url=http://www.alaskasworld.com/Newsroom/QXNews/QXstories/QX_20090203_105925.asp |publisher=Alaska Air Group |date=2009-02-03 |accessdate=2009-09-20}} * N437QX for the [[Boise State University]] Broncos, to celebrate over twenty-five years of service to Boise.{{cite web|url=http://news.boisestate.edu/newsrelease/122008/1218horizonair.shtml|title=Horizon Air to Fly Boise State Colors, Honoring Its 25-Year Service to City|date=2008-12-18|work=Office of Communications and Marketing|publisher=[[Boise State University]]|accessdate=2009-09-20}} * N440QX for the [[Oregon State University]] Beavers. This plane is Horizon Air's first "Next Gen" Q400, outfitted with a modernized interior featuring LED lighting, larger overhead bins, and scalloped sidewall panels with sun shades. ==Services== Many of the airline's services are the same as those offered by Alaska Airlines, which is Horizon Air's sister company. ===Board Room=== Board Room is the Alaska Air Group [[airport lounge]], and are located in seven west coast airports including: [[Ted Stevens Anchorage International Airport|Anchorage]], [[Los Angeles International Airport|Los Angeles]], [[Portland International Airport|Portland]], [[San Francisco International Airport|San Francisco]], and [[Seattle-Tacoma International Airport|Seattle]]. Board Room Members also have access to Delta Air Lines Sky Club at airports across the country. Memberships start at $45 for a single-day pass, up to $875 for a new three-year membership.{{cite web|url=http://www.alaskaair.com/as/www2/Flights/Boardroom/Membership-Fees.asp|title=Board Room Membership Fees|publisher=Alaska Air Group|accessdate=2009-09-14}} ===Mileage Plan=== [[File:AAG Mileage Plan logo.jpg|right|alt=The words Alaska Airlines Mileage Plan and an airplane tail with an Eskimo head]] Mileage Plan is the travel rewards program of the Alaska Air Group, Alaska Airlines and Horizon Air. The program's airline partners also include [[Oneworld]] member airlines [[American Airlines]], [[British Airways]], [[Cathay Pacific]], [[LAN Airlines|LAN]], and [[Qantas]]; [[SkyTeam]] member airlines [[Air France]], [[Continental Airlines]] (until October 24, 2009), [[Delta Air Lines]], and [[Northwest Airlines]]; as well as [[Air Pacific]], [[Era Aviation]], [[Frontier Alaska]], [[Mokulele Airlines]], and [[PenAir]].{{cite web|url=http://www.alaskaair.com/as/mileageplan/MileagePartners_Airline.asp|title=Mileage Plan Airline Partners|publisher=Alaska Air Group|accessdate=2009-09-14}} MVP and MVP Gold are Mileage Plan's top tiers for experienced travelers.{{cite web|url=http://www.alaskaair.com/as/mileageplan/AboutMP.asp|title=Mileage Plan Program Benefits|publisher=Alaska Air Group|accessdate=2009-09-14}} The Mileage Plan program has no membership fee and any mileage will be valid to the last day of the 24th month following the month of the last flight or transaction date. In addition, if a Mileage Plan member does not accumulate mileage within nine months after becoming a member, or a Mileage Plan member's account remains inactive at zero mileage for a consecutive 24 month period, the Mileage Plan account will be canceled.{{cite news|url=http://www.alaskaair.com/as/mileageplan/faqs/OtherMP.asp|title=Other Mileage Plan Information|publisher=Alaska Air Group|accessdate=2009-09-14}} ====MVP and MVP Gold==== The MVP and MVP Gold program is the frequent flyer service status program and is divided into two membership levels, MVP and MVP Gold based on the member's travel in the last calendar year. Higher-tiered members are provided with increased travel benefits such as bonus mileage, priority boarding and airport lounge access.{{cite web|url=http://www.alaskaair.com/as/mileageplan/mvpstatus.asp|title=MVP & MVP Gold Qualification Levels and Benefits|publisher=Alaska Air Group|accessdate=2009-09-14}} =====MVP===== MVP level is achieved or retained when the member earns {{convert|20000|mi|km}} on Alaska Airlines or Horizon Air, {{convert|25000|mi|km}} on Alaska Airlines, Horizon Air, American Airlines, Delta Air Lines, KLM, Air France, or LAN Airlines, or 30 one-way segments on any combination of Mileage Plan members. Membership benefits include 50 percent bonus mileage, priority check-in at First Class counters, priority seating on board Alaska Airlines and Horizon Air flights, as well as a 50 percent discount on Board Room membership. Members booked in fare class Y and YAS can be upgraded to First Class at anytime, and all other rate categories with in 48 hours of flight. =====MVP Gold===== MVP level is achieved or retained when the member earns {{convert|40000|mi|km}} on Alaska Airlines or Horizon Air, {{convert|50000|mi|km}} on Alaska Airlines, Horizon Air, American Airlines, Delta Air Lines, KLM, Air France, LAN, or Northwest Airlines, or 60 one-way segments on any combination of Mileage Plan members. Membership benefits include 100 percent bonus mileage, priority check-in at First Class counters, priority seating on board Alaska Airlines and Horizon Air flights, as well as complimentary Board Room membership. Members booked in fare class Y, S, B, M, H, or Value and Full Flex fares can be upgraded to First Class at anytime, and all other rate categories with in 72 hours of flight. Companions also receive this benefit, and members are given four complimentary upgrade certificates for guests annually. A {{convert|50000|mi|km|adj=on}} bonus is awarded to MVP Gold members who travel at least {{convert|75000|mi|km}} on Alaska Airlines, Horizon Air, American Airlines, Air France, Delta Air Lines, LAN, KLM, or Northwest Airlines, or 100 total one-way segments. ===On board services=== Since 1991, [[Starbucks]] coffee is served in-flight on all Horizon Air flights, and is brewed at the terminal and served in thermos containers on board the aircraft.{{cite news|url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19900517&slug=1072326|title=Starbucks In Flight|date=1990-05-17|work=[[The Seattle Times]]|accessdate=2008-10-11}} Horizon has set itself apart from its sister company and other airlines by offering, to passengers of age, free Northwest beer and wine.{{cite book|last=Goldsmith|first=Philip|title=Northern California Wine Country|publisher=Moon Handbooks|edition=2nd|page=402|isbn=978-1-59880-078-4|year=2008}} Other free beverages include [[Coca-Cola]] products, [[Talking Rain]] sparkling water, juices, and tea.http://www.alaskaair.com/content/travel-info/food-beverage/food-horizon.aspx Horizon also offers a limited buy on board meal service. This includes a variety of snack packs and Umpqua Oats All Natural Oatmeal Unlike Alaska Airlines, there are currently no plans to install in flight [[wireless internet]] on board Horizon Air planes.{{cite web|url=http://www.alaskaair.com/www2/help/faqs/inflightwififaq.aspx|title=Inflight Wi-Fi|publisher=Alaska Air Group|accessdate=2009-10-07}} == Incidents and accidents == Since the founding, no fatal accidents have occurred. * On May 2, 1986, a [[Fairchild Swearingen Metroliner|Fairchild Metroliner]] was [[Aircraft hijacking|hijacked]] between [[Eugene, Oregon]] and [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]]. The pilot convinced the hijacker to allow the plane to stop in [[Hillsboro, Oregon|Hillsboro]] to refuel and even let the pilot off the plane, who then called the FBI.Endicott 2001, pg. 191-194 * On April 15, 1988, Flight 2658, a DeHavilland Canada Dash 8-100 (N819PH-Great City of Sun Valley), enroute from Seattle to Spokane with 37 passenger and 3 crew members, crashed after attempting an emergency landing in [[Seattle]], [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]] when the number two (right side/[[starboard]]) engine caught fire (due to a manufacturing defect) after take-off from Seattle. Loss of hydraulic pressure due to the fire caused the aircraft to veer off the runway, across the grass, across Taxiway B and crash into the B7 and B9 jetways, destroying the plane. There were 4 serious injuries and no fatalities.{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/ntsb/brief.asp?ev_id=20001213X25438&key=1|title=DCA88MA052|date=1990-04-24|publisher=[[National Transportation Safety Board]]|accessdate=2008-10-11}}{{cite news|url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=940DE5DF123DF935A25757C0A96E948260|title= 18 Injured in Seattle Plane Crash|date=1988-04-16|work=via the [[Associated Press|AP]]|publisher=''[[New York Times|New York Times, The]]''|accessdate=2008-10-11}} * On May 23, 1990, a Fairchild Metroliner III on a flight from Portland to Seattle suffered a window blowout at {{convert|14000|ft|m}} above [[Olympia, Washington|Olympia]]. The flight made an emergency descent and landing to its planned destination of Sea-Tac Airport. The passenger seated next to the window, who was partially sucked out of the plane for a brief period, was taken to a local hospital where he was treated for his injuries and released.{{cite news|url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19900523&slug=1073398|title=Passenger Nearly Sucked Out Of Horizon Airliner|last=Tomas|first=Guillen|coauthors=Corr, O. Casey; Birkland, Dave; Lane, Polly; Whitely, Peyton|date=1990-05-23|publisher=''[[The Seattle Times|Seattle Times, The]]''|accessdate=2008-10-11}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/ntsb/brief.asp?ev_id=20001212X23280&key=1|title=NTSB Incident Report|accessdate=2009-11-12}} == See also == {{Portal box|Seattle|Companies|Aviation}} * [[Alaska Air Group]] - Parent company * [[Alaska Airlines]] - [[Mainline (flight)|Mainline]] airline co-subsidiary of Horizon's regional operations {{-}} == References == * {{cite book|last=Endicott|first=Bill|title=Remember the Magicâ¦ The Story of Horizon Air|editor=Williams, Dayna Spear|publisher=[[Turner Publishing Company]]|year=2001|isbn=978-1-56311-725-1}} {{Reflist|2}} == External links == {{Commons category}} * [http://www.horizonair.com/ Horizon Air] * [http://www.horizonairmagazine.com/ Horizon Air Magazine in flight magazine] {{Alaska Airlines}} {{Airlines of the United States}} [[Category:Regional airlines of the United States]] [[Category:Regional Airline Association members]] [[Category:Companies based in Seattle, Washington]] [[Category:Airlines established in 1981]] [[ca:Horizon Air]] [[cs:Horizon Air]] [[de:Horizon Air]] [[es:Horizon Air]] [[fr:Horizon Air]] [[he:×××¨××××× ××××¨]] [[ja:ãã©ã¤ã¾ã³èªç©º]] [[pl:Horizon Air]] [[ru:Horizon Air]]
